about_text: A flagship deep-time storyworld inspired by Stapledon: twenty iterations of humanity that escape the solar cul-de-sac, guided and contested by a Counter Archivist, culminating in endgame civilizations that emerge from a small set of civilizational traits.
storyworld_title: First and Last Men: Escape from the Solar Cul-de-sac

characters.name: The Counter Archivist
characters.description: A patient anti-institution that keeps a mirror-ledger of power: it cancels quiet influence with evidence, leaks, and paradox-proof memory.

prompt_script.value: In the 1th iteration, humanity is no longer a species so much as a design constraint. Their bodies, values, and tempo drift. A new baseline is declared, and everything older becomes a myth with sharp edges.
Scale arrives. A crisis that cannot be solved inside one planet or one polity presses on the era until it either coheres, fragments, or evaporates into software and legend.
They choose what counts as a 'self'. Some keep flesh as a sacrament. Some dissolve into templates. Some split into clades that cannot understand each other except through translated math.

This era refuses the solar cul-de-sac. They build a route that is not just travel, but a change in what space means: slow ships, engineered suns, worm-thin shortcuts, or world-lines braided into something stranger.
The Counter Archivist presents a mirror-ledger: hidden costs, canceled lies, and proof that some triumphs were theft. The era must decide whether to integrate the mirror or smash it and live blind.
Whatever else collapses, one artifact persists: a monument, a library, a protocol, a single sentence carved into vacuum. It becomes the bridge by which the next Men inherit both power and regret.

text_script.value: Let the next Men inherit. (The archive closes, then reopens in a new shape.)

text_script.value: Open the long horizon. (The archive yields; the Council assembles.)

encounters.title: Endgame: The Council of Long Horizons

prompt_script.value: The 20th Men are not one civilization but a chamber of translations. They meet across proofs, myths, and machine dreams. The Counter Archivist arrives with a mirror-ledger, insisting the ending must be earned, not chosen.

text_script.value: Offer wonder as discipline. (The future becomes an art that does not blink.)
Offer wonder as discipline. (No single ending can hold you. The Mosaic takes you.)
Offer endurance as worship. (Promises get heavier than stars.)
Offer endurance as worship. (Endurance alone is not enough. The Mosaic takes you.)
Offer transgression as method. (Reality becomes negotiable.)
Offer transgression as method. (You choose horizons you can touch.)
Offer transgression as method. (You scatter into many futures.)

prompt_script.value: A civilization that turns reality into art without lying to itself. Paradise is not escape; it is a disciplined aesthetic of truth.
A slow, austere intelligence that outlasts stars. It keeps promises in a thinning universe and treats rarity like scripture.
They harvest gravity and time. Black holes become engines, temples, and roads. Their wonder is measured in horizons.
They treat the universe as a contract with loopholes. When they find one, they rewrite the clause, and reality flinches.
They abandon bodies and even simulations, choosing to persist as transmissible stories and proofs that can reboot a mind anywhere.
No single ending wins. The future becomes a portfolio: many forms, many ethics, stitched together by careful translation.
